data.title: Eurovision musicology blog 2024
data.meta_description: Joe Bennett's annual Eurovision musicology commentary, with song & lyric analysis, and pre-voting predictions.
data.text:
Winners vs predictions

[the next day]

Phew! What an intense evening. One media outlet described it as ‚Äúbeset by chaos‚Äù, and there was certainly a lot of drama ‚Äì from the last minute disqualification of the Netherlands entry to the various geo-political gestures and commentaries. My team and I did pretty well this year ‚Äì we predicted the top 2 (juxtaposed) and all 7 of my Top 10 nods were correct.

The blogging highlight for me was the discovery/invention of the EPC (Eurovision Population Coefficient) statistic ‚Äì see Luxembourg commentary below. It‚Äôs a way of measuring Eurovision winning history per head of population (Luxembourg, Ireland, and Estonia lead the pack). I hope this can become a thing at Eurovision from now on.

Original live* analysis and predictions below

Welcome to the Eurovision live musicology blog, now in its 13th year. For context, here‚Äôs the 2020 10-year corpus research summary, and the archive of all the posts in reverse order.

Tonight I‚Äôm pleased to welcome guest blogger and UK-based copyright analyst Maddy Plummer, who has provided additional research, as well as her own reviews for UK, Austria, Armenia, Spain, Cyprus and Portugal. Additional research was provided by the estimable Rafi Waters, who has done a terrific job working on the BPMs and chord loops. I should also add that he is graduating from Berklee today ‚Äì congratulations Rafi!

As always, I‚Äôve provided commentary on each song, so you can follow along with the show, or (later) watch the embedded videos. And I‚Äôm going to try to predict the winner, before voting begins, then leave the prediction up here for posterity when the votes are in.

Americans ‚Äì the show goes out live at 3pm Eastern time on Saturday May 11, 2024. You can watch live with a free Peacock TV account.

Europeans ‚Äì you know the drill.

* I have actually pre-blogged everything based on the Spotify Eurovision finalists playlist, but the blog is published on the day of the final (before the voting begins) so should be read live alongside the show as it is broadcast.

Predictions 2024

Here are my predictions for 2024, made at 12.50 US Eastern time (18.50 Swedish time), before the show starts in Malm√∂:

Croatia

Switzerland

Israel

France, Ukraine, Ireland, and Italy to place in the top 10.

(I‚Äôll be watching the show as it goes out, so may change these predictions as I see the performances ‚Äì but will be sure to lock it all down before voting begins!)

Let‚Äôs do this!

01 üá∏üá™ ‚Ä¢ Sweden ‚Ä¢ Unforgettable

Marcus & Martinus ‚Ä¢ 117 ‚Ä¢ C#m

Songwriters: Jimmy ‚ÄúJoker‚Äù Th√∂rnfeldt, Joy Deb, Linnea Deb, Marcus Gunnarsen, Martinus Gunnarsen

What a great way to open the show. Yes, I know the opener and closer are randomly selected, but the dice have fallen fortuitously tonight (more on dice-rolling when we get to Greece later on). This is the sort of thing we‚Äôve come to expect from the Swedes ‚Äì Electro-pop minor-key bangers, sung in English at around 120BPM with pounding analogue synths, super dry four-on-the-floor kick drum, and lots of those ‚Äòrisers‚Äô ‚Äì the rocket-effect synth lifts that take you into each chorus. Similar songs include ‚ÄúEuphoria‚Äù by Loreen (2012), ‚ÄúHeroes‚Äù by M√•ns Zelmerl√∂w (2015), ‚ÄúDance You Off‚Äù by Benjamin Ingrosso (2018), and of course last year‚Äôs winner ‚ÄúTattoo‚Äù by Loreen (2023). And what‚Äôs to hate? They do it so well. This is why my pretty good ESC batting average holds up ‚Äì I always believe in Sweden.

Marcus and Martinus‚Äôs performance looks ‚Äì and sounds ‚Äì like the VR game Beat Saber. The arrangement is all rising ramps. The kick drum stays away until the second verse ‚Äúchew you up‚Äù, then drops out after only 8 bars so the first pre-chorus has no drums at all. Then everything drips in during the first chorus over each title repeat: kick and bass, then 2x octave synth, short drums tacet for 2 beats, giving us space to feel the beat on the next prechorus. It‚Äôs as if a DJ took over the songwriting, and this technique ‚Äì of simply dropping instruments in and out ‚Äì creates a fantastic journey for the dance floor, if it‚Äôs used with the right timing. I love the extra bar just before the title hook, manipulating the phrase length to keep the dancers interested (it‚Äôs an old ABBA trick). For me, it feels like it never quite hits top gear. This is partly because the melody never goes beyond a limited range of a 5th ‚Äì highest note is G#4, lowest is C#4. And the chord loop is (understandably) the same throughout ‚Äì | C#m | C#m | A | F#m |.

So this is another one of ‚Äúthose Swedish dance songs‚Äù that Eurovision has loved so many times. It‚Äôs good, but not exceptional enough to stick in the memory after the laser lights have faded. Maybe that title is asking for too much.

02 üá∫üá¶ ‚Ä¢ Ukraine ‚Ä¢ Teresa & Maria

alyona alyona & J. Heil ‚Ä¢ 114 ‚Ä¢ G Aeolian

Songwriters: Aliona Savranenko, Anton Chilibi, Ivan Klymenko, Yana Shemaieva

In my 2020 Eurovision research we analysed 259 ESC songs 2010-2019 and categorised them according to various themes: Love, Unity, Self-Assertion, Partying, History, and songs about music/dancing. ‚ÄúTeresa & Maria‚Äù covers at least three of these, plus Catholicism, old-school seasonal metaphysics, anti-war sentiments, and life-is-short existentialism thrown in. The message seems to be ‚Äúseize the day‚Äù and Jerry and alyona are selling it well with some joyful vocals and an in-yer-face rap breakdown section. Sonically, it‚Äôs an updated Enigma approach; with hypnotic chanting vocals over a Euro-friendly chord loop | Gm F | Cm Eb | and a super basic four on the floor rock beat.

We know there‚Äôs a lot of love for the Ukranians right now, and I think this is as good as their winning ‚ÄúStefania‚Äù from 2022 (similar approach in the chorus vocals). It‚Äôs good. But is it good enough to beat the Croatians?

03 üá©üá™ ‚Ä¢ Germany ‚Ä¢ Always on the Run

Isaak ‚Ä¢ 110 ‚Ä¢ Bb minor

Songwriters: Greg Taro / Isaak Guderian / Kevin Lehr / Leo Jupiter

A song of struggling with demons, and trying to deal with the pressures of everyday life. But if Isaak‚Äôs smiley and charismatic performance is any indicator, he seems pretty happy with his lot. The delivery is very Lewis Capaldi, and I suspect his selection at Germany‚Äôs ‚ÄúDas deutsche Finale‚Äù had something to do with his great vocal tone. Clearly the writing team wants to exploit that, so we hear parts of Always On The Run in two different octaves, with the bridge ‚ÄúRun from the silence, screamin‚Äô for guidance‚Äù beginning in his baritone range, bottoming out at c#3. When it goes up the octave 4 bars later he has to hit A#4 ‚Äì quite a spread for (what sounds to me like) an intuitive, non-trained singer. Given that my first listens were based on the German national final, he wasn‚Äôt quite managing the lower pitches accurately when singing live (and remember the ESC rules require lead vocals to be fully live). So I‚Äôm listening carefully to see if he nails it.

Harmonically, we‚Äôre in the ESC-friendly Aeolian mode (natural minor scale). Everything is a 4 or 8-bar loop harmonically; the verses are | Bbm | Bbm | Db | Db | Ebm | Ebm | Bbm | Bbm | (oooh distorted plectrum electric bass ‚Äì nice!) and the chorus paces up the harmonic rhythm | Gb | Ebm | Bbm | Ab | (x2). The ‚ÄúRun from the silence‚Äù bridge uses the chorus chords in a different order | Gb | Ebm | Bbm | Ab | (x4). If the singing is on the money tonight, I‚Äôd place this on in the upper-middle of the pack.

80%

04 üá±üá∫ Luxembourg ‚Ä¢ Fighter

Tali ‚Ä¢ 95 ‚Ä¢ F#m

Songwriters: Manon Romiti / Silvio Lisbonne / Ana Zimmer / Dardust

Luxemburg is back! They have been absent from the contest since 1993. Before that, they won a remarkable 5 times (1961, 1965, 1972, 1973, 1983) ‚Äì not bad for a country of less than a million people.

This information has inspired me to create a new statistics game. If we know the population of a European country, the number of times they‚Äôve entered Eurovision, and the number of times they‚Äôve won, we can create a win-rate ‚Äòscore‚Äô, prorated for the size of the country. I‚Äôm going to call it the ‚ÄúEurovision Population Coefficient‚Äù (EPC). It measures the proportional level of Eurovision-win talent in each citizen. Here is the formula.

If we multiply this number by 1 million this provides a wins-per-million (WPM) stat in the population. Here are the EPC scores across the whole history of the Contest 1956-2023, for the top 20 of tonight‚Äôs finalists. As expected, Luxembourg has the highest EPC by a huge margin. To beat them, Ireland is going to have to really ramp up the wins in future. Or join the Schengen area and start a mass emigration scheme to Luxembourg‚Ä¶

Luxembourg: Wins 5, Entries 38, Population 0.63M, EPC 1035.65

Ireland: Wins 7, Entries 54, Population 4.99M, EPC 163.83

Portugal: Wins 1, Entries 53, Population 10.28M, EPC 0.18

Germany: Wins 2, Entries 64, Population 83.2M, EPC 0.01

Anyway, back to the song. Luxembourg are celebrating their return with this fun upper-middle-ranking entry. More of the almost-cumbia minor-key groove material that we‚Äôve seen so much of in the last 10 years or so (and more since Despacito). For me, there are two really cool bits ‚Äì the ‚Äúhah!‚Äù in the middle of each chorus and the ‚ÄúJ‚Äôavoue, j‚Äôavoue, je sais pas, je veux tout et rien √† la fois‚Äù bizarre but arresting harmonic minor run at the end ‚Äì where did that come from? The indomitable spirit of the lyric stands out ‚Äì sort of Firework meets You‚Äôve Got a Friend. Not a lot of win potential, but it‚Äôs good to have them back.

05 üáÆüá± ‚Ä¢ Israel ‚Ä¢ Hurricane

Eden Golan ‚Ä¢ 87 ‚Ä¢ Em

[Please note: The ESC is a non-political event, and this blog ‚Äì and my commentary ‚Äì is exclusively about music and songwriting.]

This is a great vocal, and although it‚Äôs right on the edge of predictable diatonic-piano-ballad-by-numbers, I think the voters are going to go for it. The chorus opening ‚Äúpromise me you‚Äôll hold me again‚Äù starts off on a chord of Am, with Eden leaning on the same/equivalent note as starts France‚Äôs Mon Amour. There are a couple of moments where the safeness recedes ‚Äì I like the cross-beat rhymes of the pre chorus ‚ÄúHours and hours, empowers / Life is no game but it‚Äôs ours‚Äù. The production gives us some great ear candy ‚Äì the 8th-note echoed water droplets after chorus 1 are very cool ‚Äì and Eden does a great job with the up-the-octave theme after the final chorus. The chorus chord loop feels familiar but isn‚Äôt ‚Äì it‚Äôs actually quite tough to find a lot of songs with (in G major) | Am | Em | G | D | (ii-vi-I-V). Quite an achievement to find a relatively unusual combination of the world‚Äôs favourite chords!

As disclaimer‚Äôd above, I make no comment on the politics, but I think this one could do really well.

06 üá±üáπ Lithuania ‚Ä¢ Luktelk

Silvester Belt ‚Ä¢ 140 ‚Ä¢ E minor

Songwriters: Silvestras Beltƒó (Silvester Belt) , D≈æesika ≈†yvokaitƒó (Jessica Shy) & Elena Jurgaitytƒó (Elayork)

Starts boldly, with the filtered organ part from The Who‚Äôs Won‚Äôt Get Fooled Again. Then the beat drops, and it‚Äôs pretty sparse ‚Äì techno drum machine and synth bass all the way. This is one of many songs tonight that deals with themes of emergence, opportunity, breaking the routine, and finding fulfilment, perhaps through love. ‚ÄòLuktelk‚Äô means ‚Äòwait‚Äô, and it seems to be an exhortation to understanding, as the protagonist shares his responsibility to dance & party, even though he initially doesn‚Äôt feel it. I admire the bleak-at-first glance couplet ‚ÄúStovime tyloje grojanƒçio radijo / Nebenoriu ≈°okt, nebenoriu ≈°okt‚Äù (‚ÄúWe‚Äôre standing in the silence of the radio playing / I don‚Äôt wanna dance, but I have to dance.‚Äù). Being stuck indoors throughout 2020 sure did get some songwriters dreaming of a better tomorrow.

The musical backbone of the verses and choruses is a 2-chord 4-bar pattern | Em | Em | Bm | Bm |, apart from a short post-chorus section with no drums that briefly takes us to G major, and also the bridge, which is a descending | Em | D | C | A |. I particularly liked that A major chord at the end of the first repeat, bringing just 4 beats of dorian mode to the song, which is enough of a surprise for the 2-chord loop to drive a sense of chorus-y familiarity when it returns.

Silvester is a deeply engaging performer ‚Äì he‚Äôs dancing throughout and enjoying the moment, all the while waving his arms as if he‚Äôs spinning invisible DJ decks. This is one for the after-show party.

Nebulossa ‚Ä¢ 130 ‚Ä¢ A minor

Songwriters: Mar√≠a Jos√© Bas Arguijo / Giner Puchol Lorenzo

[Guest review by Maddy Plummer]

Couple goals? Enter wife and husband Spanish pop duo Nebulossa! Initially criticised for being ‚Äòoverly sexist‚Äô, the lyrics for this song were rewritten. Quick etymology lesson: The title of the song, repeated multiple times in the lyrics, literally means ‚Äúvixen‚Äù (i.e. a female fox), however I have come to understand that in Spanish slang, ‚ÄòZorra,‚Äô is a derogatory term for a woman and has vulgar connotations. Adding insult to injury, the euphemistic meaning of the male equivalent, ‚ÄòZorro‚Äô, has positive connotations. Let‚Äôs see how the attempt to reappropriate and subvert the term translates on the live stage; historically speaking, meta-commentary has not always been palatably received among Eurovision‚Äôs more earnest folk, (see Mae Muller 2023, who came 25th). The song itself has an 80s-feel four-to-the-floor electro beat (complete with Simmons drums on stage!). The slow-release low-pass filter on the intro is straight out of Madonna‚Äôs Stuck On You, which combines well with Mar√≠a‚Äôs soft monosyllabic vocals. The formulaic structure prevents much musical progression, but the chord sequence of F / G / Am / Em with the emphatic ascending minor pentatonic fragment of A / D/ E / G in the bass at the end of each chorus, is a great compositional choice. The vocal is somehow simultaneously sullen and vibrant, which works well in conjunction with the brash and outrageously satirical lyrics. A genuinely interesting entry, I hope the voters have a dark sense of humour.

[Guest review by musicologist (and British citizen!) Maddy Plummer]

Has Olly Alexander saved us from national embarrassment with a revival of disco? A BAFTA nominated actor and already well established frontman from chart topping band Years & Years, famous for songs like ‚ÄòKing‚Äô and ‚ÄòDesire‚Äô, Alexander is confidently striking out on his own. Fellow music theory geeks will recognise the chord progression here as a circle of fourths; think of Gloria Gaynor‚Äôs ‚ÄòI Will Survive‚Äô or more recently Miley Cyrus‚Äô ‚ÄòFlowers‚Äô [also Fly Me To The Moon, 50 Ways To Say Goodbye, You Never Give Me Your Money, It‚Äôs a Sin etc]. The main hook in the chorus is simple but catchy. The dotted melody consistently oscillates between major and minor thirds as it descends. The contrast of the melody against the rhythmically straight and strong bass beat helps us really lean into the title‚Äôs theme. Alexander‚Äôs lyrics sing of a hedonistic, all-consuming desire to go to a euphoric state of timeless ‚Äòdizziness‚Äô with his lover. There‚Äôs a nod to wedding church bells, albeit slightly tongue in cheek especially with the Eurovision-themed ‚Äúwill you take my hand‚Äù. Olly‚Äôs spoken-word bridge is reminiscent of Pet Shop Boys, providing some much-needed contrast with the verses, but lacks power. Harle‚Äôs production uses arpeggiators to provide the majority of the interest under the vocals. The success of this song will likely come down to the performance, Eurovision is as changeable as British weather, so let‚Äôs hope for a downpour of glitter and energy!

In case you‚Äôre wondering, this is a ramonda.

It is also known as the Serbian Phoenix Flower, and it is noted for its ability to ‚Äòrise from the dead‚Äô after cold winters. In Serbia it is a symbol of hope and renewal, and often associated with the WWI armistice day of 11 November 1918. There are many conflict remembrance flowers, including the poppy (UK, France, Belgium, Ukraine), cornflower (Germany), corn poppy (Poland), Easter lily (Ireland) and daisy (Italy).

Teya has provided us with an anti-war song that can also be interpreted as any kind of rising-from-the-ashes message. It‚Äôs a simple Aeolian ballad, leaning heavily on Am and F changes, but the simplicity of the melody doesn‚Äôt jar on me at all; the only lyric in the chorus is ‚Äúlila ramonda‚Äù (lilac ramonda), and that‚Äôs all it needs.

And don‚Äôt doubt the Serbs‚Äô ability to do well in their native language: they won in 2007, their first year they entered as an independent country, with Marija ≈†erifoviƒá‚Äôs Molitva, sung entirely in Serbian.

The orchestration follows the usual wedge-of-cheese ESC road map for big ballads ‚Äì poignant piano vocal opening, building instrument by instrument into strings, choir, drums and bass for the the belting final chorus, followed by an on-the-barline dynamic drop for the final 4 bars where we go back to piano/vocal, as the animated ramonda opens on the final beat. In terms of songwriting technique, this is a great example of the power of using a concrete noun hook to focus the lyric theme. I found it really affecting.

Songwriters: Anderz Wrethov, Jimmy Th√∂rnfeldt, Julie Aagaard, and Thomas Stengaard

Rooted in Armenian folk music and nurtured within the vein of Latin American, Russian and contemporary pop influences, this is a celebration of culture and musically very colourful. It is composed in the D Phrygian Dominant mode with an unusual chord sequence of D, Eb, D, Cm (D), not typically heard within mainstream Western music which sadly may not successfully translate in a commercial tone. The use of sparse texture while she sings the main chorus hook consecutively followed by unison instrumentation is highly effective in invoking that celebratory tone; as if she is shouting ‚Äòall together now‚Äô! This also feels like a great opportunity for audience interaction. I worry that some may not realise the depth of the song‚Äôs meaning; a self-titled ode to her own freedom and empowerment ‚Äì Jako is a nickname for the Ladaniva‚Äôs lead singer Jaklin. The upbeat tone may not fully convey Jaklin‚Äôs criticism of female societal expectations and there is a danger of it being shrugged off as merely a party song. The recorder solo by French multi-instrumentalist Louis Thomas feels well placed among this year‚Äôs many folk instruments. A charismatic duo not to be overlooked, we will likely all be shouting ‚ÄòJako!‚Äô at our TVs after the first chorus.

For the verse ‚Äúput out the fire‚Äù we‚Äôre hearing the son clave with an occasional dry kick drum, then when the pre-chorus picks up ‚Äúthe ceiling is falling‚Äù it switches to the reggaeton feel.
